div.p: 1. Petition of Betsey Rogers and 103 women of New-Hampshire, Plymouth, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia—
Petition of Phebe Little and 51 women of Campton New-Hampshire, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia—

2.— Petition of Thomas Williams and 75 and 48. 123 Citizens of Vernon, Oneida County, New-York, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia and the Territories—prohibiting the internal and coasting Slave-trade and the exportation of Slaves to Texas or the dominions of any foreign power.

Petition of Joseph Rolette and 47. Citizens of Crawford County, Wisconsin Territory, complaining that by the Proclamation of the Governor Henry Dodge they are not duly represented in the Legislative Council of the Territory, and praying an Act of Congress for Redress— (With 4. Documents.)
Referred to Comee on the Territories

Petition of Huldah Pennyman, widow of Bethuel Pennyman, of Abington Masstts. for 7 years half pay and interest, as once widow of Barnabas Hollis of Braintree a soldier of the Revolution who served between 3 and 4. years as Sergeant in Coll. Sheldon’s troop of horse—and was slain— (Letter from Reuben Baldwin)
Referred to the Comee. on Revolutionary Pensions.
Petition of James G. Crane and 251. Citizens of Detroit, Michigan, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia.
(With Letter from Arthur Livermore Porter—)
Petition-Letter of Elias Ware—a Revolutionary Pensioner, for arrears of Pension from 4. March 1820 to 10. Augt. 1826 while he was struck off the list.
Referred to Comee of the whole on invalid Pension Committee’s Bills
Petition of John M’Crillis, and 180 inhabitants of Somersworth, Strafford County New-Hampshire to prohibit the Slave trade between the States.
Petition of George W. Roberts with 19 men and 33 women inhabitants of Somersworth, New Hampshire, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia—
Petition of Mary M. Smith and 240 women, of Great Falls— New-Hampshire, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia.
Petition of Benjamin C. Sewall and 180 Citizens of Somersworth New Hampshire for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia—
Petition of 9 women, dated Fredericsburg Virginia to put a stop to the Slave trade in the District of Columbia—
With Letter from Susan Loushing.
3. Petition of Nathaniel H. Whiting; and 254 legal voters of Abington, Massachusetts for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia—
Petition of Anna Holbrook and 300 women of Abington, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia.

Buddey Taylorre and 21 names of self-declared Slaves, praying that the abolition Gentlemen, may abandon their pursuit, and that in case the Gentlemen from the Northern States, continue to urge their petitions on this subject, the said Gentlemen be expunged from his Seat in the Congress—
4. Petition of Walter Smith, and 41. Inhabitants of New market, New-Hampshire, for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia
5. Petition of John Codman and 127. Citizens of Dorchester Masstts. for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia.

Petition of Convers Francis and 30 Citizens of Watertown, Massachusetts for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade in the District of Columbia.

Petition of Mrs T. L. Hodges and 64. Women of Taunton and Petition of Clarissa H. Reed and 22 women of Taunton, Massachusetts; for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia—

Petition of Evelina Reed and 18 Minors of Taunton Massachusetts, praying for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and the Slave-trade. To annul all municipal ordinances which make any distinction between persons of different colours, and to provide for the education of all coloured children in the District.
Petition of Elvira Tenney and 114 women of New-Ipswich, New-Hampshire for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia—

Petition of A. H. Stevens and 298 Citizens of Richland, Sandy Creek Oswego Co. New-York for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia, to prohibit the internal and coasting Slave trade and the exportation of Slaves to Texas or the dominions of any foreign power—
received from Mr Turrill
Petition of David Loud a Soldier of the late War; for money in the place of a military land-warrant
Referred to Comee of invalid Pensions
32. Abolition Petitions laid on the table under the general order of 18 Jany

Memorial of Leonard Bacon and 8 Citizens of New Haven Connecticut, praying for Laws to protect the domestic Relations of all the Inhabitants, of the District of Columbia—

Bingham and 332 Citizens of Salina, Onondaga County—New-York for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia and the Territories, the prohibition of the internal and Coasting Slave trade and of the exportation of Slaves to Mexico, or the dominions of any foreign power.
